utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, I’m zeroing out the electro-osmotic flow rate in the micro-fluidic channel.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nicely done, Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, my wife is four-foot-ten and sexually satisfied, so clearly I know my way around tiny things.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good for you, on the cutting edge of new technology and still making inappropriate comments about the mother of your child.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Those are just the things I say out loud.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Gentlemen, we need to stop immediately.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What’s wrong?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m looking at the math, and I think we can make the device between eight and ten percent smaller.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s great, but the Air Force approved the specs. We’re good to go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah. It doesn’t need to be smaller.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Shame on you. Where would we be if poodle breeders had that attitude? I’ll tell you. We would have the standard and the miniature poodle, but no toy or teacup. Which by the way, is not an officially recognized breed, but that’s just poodle politics.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can we please stop talking about poodles?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine. Candy bars. Now, do you enjoy a fun size? I know you do.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, we don’t need to make this smaller, and your work is done. Go home.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t want to go home.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fine, go for a little walk.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then what?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just keep walking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: At least it’s quiet when he takes bathroom breaks.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I know. That’s why I keep refilling his water when he’s not looking.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re kidding.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t care if we’re in a drought, it’s worth it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, I do have a way to get him out of our hair. I’ve been holding onto this for a few years, but maybe now’s the time.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We can just lock the door, you don’t have to kill him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You can’t kill him, he’ll just respawn at the last save point.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that was my sixth trip to the bathroom. As long as that’s not a urinary tract infection, that’s a personal best.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, uh, buddy, I got you a little present.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. Go ahead, open it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Congratulations. The bearer of this certificate is entitled to the ultimate train experience at The Nevada Northern Railway. You are at the throttle. You are the engineer. You are running the locomotive. This doesn’t happen very often, but here comes a hug. Oh, dear, I have to tinkle again.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay. Where were we?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: For Howie’s occupation, should I include that he was an astronaut?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, he mentioned it in his mother’s eulogy, so why not?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I can’t believe you have to fill out a preschool application for an infant.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Uh, the one at Caltech has a crazy wait list. I warned you, a lot of people apply when they’re still pregnant.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, I didn’t. I also skipped a birthing class to see Zootopia so back off.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Whoa. Just trying to help.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Sorry. Howie’s back at work and there’s just so much going on.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Is there anything we can do?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Sure. Open up a college fund, shop for life insurance, and in the laundry room, there’s a mountain of dirty laundry. Wash it or burn in, your choice. Ugh, be right back.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No, no. I will take care of it.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, thank you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: While I’m gone, you can think about how mean you were to me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right, you know what you need? A night away from all of this. You know, where you can just kind of relax and, I’m just gonna turn this off. Much better. Seriously, let’s plan a night, you know, give you a break. We could go dancing.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: That sounds really nice.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh. All this week, the Early Music Society of Pasadena is doing a joint concert with the San Gabriel Renaissance Choir.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, that’s the one to beat.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Good luck. People have been saying that for 600 years.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, you’re home early.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’ll never believe it. Leonard gave me the most incredible gift, a trip to a historic railway, and I get to operate an actual locomotive.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Wow. He finally used it. What’d you do?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No idea. All I know is I’m gonna be working on the railroad all the livelong day.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, I’m really happy for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no. It’s not just me. No. The railway is four hours from the nearest airport, and guess who gets to drive me.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I give up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: No. I really give up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, oh. And guess where we get to sleep? Our choice of a turn-of-the-century railway bunkhouse or a working caboose. Now, the problem with a caboose is there’s no bathroom, but the problem with the bunkhouse is it’s not a caboose. On the first day, I get to drive a steam engine. Oh, and the second day, a diesel engine. Oh, and if I volunteer to do track maintenance and paperwork, they’ll let me stay as long as I want. So you might want to pack enough clothes for the rest of our lives.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Can I pee now?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, get this. I get to take a test based on a 125-page manual. I get to learn things like hand signals. Ooh. There’s forward, uh, reverse, set the brakes. Are you done yet? You’re missing

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: This train thing worked out better than I thought. He’s home studying the engineer’s manual.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s so peaceful without him here. Can I ask you how much that cost?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Four thousand dollars, worth every penny.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: Gentlemen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Colonel Williams. Sir.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: Just wanted to see how the guidance system’s coming along.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Great. We found a cooling solution that allowed us to get the size of the prototype down to the target specs.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: As a cooling solution, it’s pretty cool.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: Don’t do that. What’s this?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, nothing. Just some math we don’t need.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: This is a different approach. Are you trying to get the guidance system even smaller?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s just a theory. Uh, it’s not even worked out.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: Oh. I want this.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But we’ve already met the agreed upon specs. Going smaller would require weeks’ worth of new computations.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: So get the kid with the two shirts to do it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sir, uh, if I may, uh, we’ve put a lot of thought and effort into this current prototype. It’s a really elegant solution, and most importantly, it works.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: Yeah, I want this.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, but that’s just a theory. It’s not even a complete thought.

utterance.speaker: Col Williams
utterance.content: You both make excellent points, and thank you for presenting it so articulately. Make this.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: The kid with the two shirts screwed us again.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right. You guys ready to get crazy?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, the bra under here ain’t beige.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay. You ladies have fun tonight.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Don’t worry about Halley. Uncle Stuart’s on the job.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Under the careful supervision of her godfather.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: My apologies. I didn’t mean to offend you, Don Corleone.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Like I said, you ladies have fun.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We will. Got my dancing shoes, got my breast pump. Let’s party.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, if you pump at the bar, I promise we’ll get free drinks.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Call if there’s any problems.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No. She’s busy. You call Howard.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Got it.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Call me. Don’t call Howard.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I would never call Howard.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Okay, instead of arguing all night, let’s just split up the baby chores.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, great. Um, I’ll put food in her top half, you deal with whatever comes out the bottom.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I can’t believe we have to ask Sheldon to come back and help us.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, boo-hoo. I spent four grand on a gift that only got rid of him for an afternoon. What is that?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, but if he yells It’s alive, we run.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, hey. If you knocked, I couldn’t hear you. I’m welding this locomotive engine. And if you didn’t knock, how about some manners?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How’d you even get that up the stairs?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I said to myself, I think I can, I think I can. And then I couldn’t, so I paid two men who promised not to come rob us later.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, look, Sheldon, the Colonel wants us to make the guidance system smaller, and we can’t do it without you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Interesting. Well, so I was right.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Open a window. It’s about to get smug in here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I would love to help you, but since I discovered the satisfaction of working with my hands on a train engine, I don’t think I can go back to theory. I’m an engineer now. And, hey, just to be clear, a train engineer. Not that goofy kind you are.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, you can still go on the trip in a few weeks. Just help us out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry. I need to work on this engine so when I get to the train yard I won’t look foolish.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: He’s worried about looking foolish. That’s a heapin’ helping of irony right there.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, you know you’re not leaving physics. Why are you doing this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard, in the world of theoretical physics, you never finish. So much is unprovable. But when I was studying that railway guide, it was so tangible and so satisfying that something just clicked. Then it clacked. Then it clicked, then it clacked, click-clack clickety-clack, and here we are. Whoo-whoo.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, did you hear anything back from the Caltech preschool?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Not yet, but we’re gonna apply to a bunch of others just to keep our options open.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, stop that. No more preschool talk. Tonight is about having fun.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Nothing says fun like being scolded.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette (phone rings)
utterance.content: Oh, it’s Raj. Everything okay?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Don’t worry. Everything’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Hang up, we don’t need help.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I don’t need your help deciding when we need help!

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Raj, what’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yes, so, I was just warming up some milk for Halley, and I thought it smelled a little funky, so I checked the date that you wrote on the bottle, and it says Flerbsday.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: It says Tuesday.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How is that a T?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m sure it’s fine, but if you’re worried, there’s extra milk in the freezer.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, yes, I will err on the side of caution and defrost a fresh batch.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: You’re wasting perfectly good milk.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fine, you drink it.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: It’s just milk.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Stuart, don’t you drink my milk.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, give. Can you guys handle this or not?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, of course we can. Uh, you girls have a good time. She said I was in charge.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Hmm. So we just throw this away?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What else are you gonna do with it? Put it in your coffee?

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Well, I don’t take it black.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay. This is everything he had on the board. I’m sure we can figure the rest out.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right. Hmm. Feel free to jump in. Hmm is all I got.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, we can get this. Is there any chance it’s upside-down?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Maybe we can find another theoretical physicist to help us.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s classified. If we tell anyone, we’d get in trouble.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, I came up with that and hmm. You haven’t pitched anything.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just keep thinking. I got it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You really figured it out?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, but when we show this nonsense to Sheldon, it will make him crazy, and he’ll have to fix it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, you’re a genius.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I know. That’s not even a math symbol. That’s just Charlie Brown’s hair.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sorry, guys. This club was so great, how could they turn it into a bookstore? I thought we got rid of all those.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Renaissance Choir’s looking pretty good right now, huh?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette (on phone)
utterance.content: Hello?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Nothing to worry about. She’s just been crying for a little while, and I was wondering if you had any tricks to get her to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: She was sleeping just fine till you took a selfie with her.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: She was blowing a spit bubble. It was adorable.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You guys got this? Do you need me to come home?

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Wait. She’s settling down.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, okay, false alarm. Little parenting tip, sleeping babies hate flash photography.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Is everything okay?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yeah. I may have just left my infant daughter with Patrick and SpongeBob.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey, there’s another dance club nearby. I mean, I don’t know how you feel about Latin music, but according to their horas of operación, they’re open.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Maybe we should just call it a night.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You sure? They’re open till dos.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yeah, we’re all dressed up. Why go home?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m just not really in the mood anymore.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What’s going on with you?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t know. This is all starting to feel like a sad attempt to recapture our youth.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m not sad. I just wanted to get drunk and not wear sweatpants.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m not sad. I mean, hello.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, maybe I’m the one who’s sad.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What are you sad about?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Maybe the fact that you went and had a baby.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You’re upset I had a baby?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, of course not. I just, I didn’t think it would make me have all these feelings.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What feelings?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Pressure. I mean, she’s looking at preschools, she has a minivan, she has a 401K. Before she talked about it, I just thought that was a race.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You think that stuff is fun? Being a parent is terrifying. I’m constantly worried, I’m always tired, and in a few minutes I’m gonna milk myself in a bookstore parking lot.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I get that, okay? It’s just, Leonard and I have been married for two years, and we’re no further along than when we were dating.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Come on. You’ve got so much to feel good about. You’ve got a great job now.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, I guess I am making decent money.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You make more than I do.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You may not have a house yet, but your apartment’s great.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s bigger than mine.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: And Leonard loves you so much, he married you twice.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m not even engaged once. I don’t even know if Sheldon thinks about marriage. I’m not getting any younger. Honestly, I kind of thought by now, we might have had some sort of…

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Careful. The sound of crying can make me lactate.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I can’t help it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, that’s gonna make me cry.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: And there they go.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ew.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, Sheldon, turns out we didn’t need you after all.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s right. We figured it out all by ourselves. Wasn’t even that hard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, good for you guys. Look, I have a grease smudge on my hand, and I’m okay with it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Aren’t you gonna look at the board to see how right we are?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, thanks. I’m busy trying to fix this fuel pump.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s a manifold.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh. Well, I guess it’s fixed.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just look at the board.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, no, what should we have done differently?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, first of all, you can’t use relativistic and non-relativistic vectors in the same equation.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Told ya. Can you fix it for us?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, but this is the last time. Nice try, blockheads.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon. You can’t turn your back on physics, and besides, you have no idea what you’re doing with this stuff.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But if you really want to learn the mechanical side, I can teach you anything you want to know.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And instead of standing around watching, you can help us build your smaller guidance system.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And with all these new skills, you’d be able to fix any model train. You’d be the king of the train store.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me. I have a girlfriend. I’m already king of the train store.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, what do you say?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, what choice do I have? You need me. I’m like the crankshaft of this team.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s a turbo.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, whatever it is, it looks heavy. I’m gonna need you two to get it downstairs before Amy comes home.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I apologize that it’s so warm in here.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It is warm in here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve worked up a bit of a sweat.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Me, too.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: May I borrow your water?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (voice)
utterance.content: The light’s green.

utterance.speaker: Amy (now in her car)
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: GPS says we’ll be at the railway in three hours.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I can get us there in two.
